comments.body: Off the logic, but we may migrate this to a pure subtest style.
I'd prefer to check if the actual error is the one expected so it doesn't fail in another place in the call tree and might not actually fail where you expect it to.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@		ttl              *int32
		since            *time.Time
		expectErr        bool
		expectErrStr     string
		expectedTimeLeft *time.Duration

comments.body:
you can merge
```golang
expectErr bool
expectErrStr     string
```
into
```
expectedErr error
```
which can contain both states and just use `err != tc.expectedError` and expected/got with `%#v`
`error` won't be equal so we should compare `err.Error()`. I think it's cleaner this way because the returned error contains the name of the job. We can discuss this in follow-up PRs.

It will be equal, if your test case represents the actual error, not a (sub)string. Job name is fixed in the test - I don't see a reason why test only part of the error and leave the other part and the type untested; it even simplifies the test logic. I don't feel strong if you choose not to follow that path.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@		ttl              *int32
		since            *time.Time
		expectErr        bool
		expectErrStr     string
		expectedTimeLeft *time.Duration
